thread.title: Hogan unblocks people from Facebook after ACLU threatens legal action
thread.title_full: Hogan unblocks people from Facebook after ACLU threatens legal action - The Washington Post

author: washingtonpost blogs
title: Hogan unblocks people from Facebook after ACLU threatens legal action
text:
February 21 at 3:34 PM Follow @FenitN Aides to Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan (R) have started to unblock people from his Facebook page after criticism over his office deleting negative comments and banning critics, and a threat of legal action from the American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland.
The organization wrote to Hogan’s office on Friday to demand a review of all 450 people banned from posting on the governor’s popular social media page. The ACLU also wanted apologies and restoration of posting privileges to seven clients the group says were unjustly banned.
The ACLU’s letter said the removal of posts violated a state social media policy urging managers to refrain from taking down antagonistic comments, as well as constitutional free-speech protections.
“The purpose of social media is to have this exchange of ideas,” said Deborah Jeon, legal director for the ACLU of Maryland. “Once that type of a forum is established by the government and the governor, it’s not permissible to say, ‘If you agree with me, you are allowed to post. And if you don’t, there’s no place for you here.’ ”
Aides to the governor say they have unblocked several of commenters who are being represented by the ACLU, but have not changed their policies on deleting off-topic or abusive comments.
“While the ACLU should be focusing on much more important activities than monitoring the governor’s Facebook page, we appreciated them identifying a handful of individuals — out of the over 1 million weekly viewers of the page — that may have been inadvertently denied access,” said Amelia Chasse, a spokeswoman for Hogan.
“We will continue to remove any and all profane, violent, racist, and political spam commentary from the Facebook page, and encourage robust, on-topic discussion.”
Hogan’s office on Tuesday highlighted examples of abusive posts removed from the Facebook page, including images of posts calling the governor a “fat racist trump loving Facist” (sic) and accusing him of “using cancer to ensure his reelection.”
But the ACLU and other critics say people have been blocked for critical posts that used clean language.
In addition, Jeon said several people had their access to Hogan’s Facebook page restored over the weekend, after Hogan’s office received the ACLU’s letter, but then found themselves blocked again this week, or discovered that their comments had been hidden.
She says the organization is considering taking further legal action, possibly including a lawsuit.
Over the weekend, Hogan pushed back online against commenters who criticized him for censoring dissenting comments. “I do not block constituents who disagree with me, that whole narrative is simply false,” he posted on Saturday.
Several posts criticizing Hogan were left up on the Facebook page Saturday and Sunday, with the governor replying to say the commenters were inaccurate or ill-informed.
The Maryland Democratic Party has been criticizing Hogan on this issue as well. In an email to supporters on Tuesday, party officials offered to hand-deliver letters of complaint to the governor’s office , and likened his removal of Facebook comments to congressional Republicans refusing to hold town halls .
